editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Homily concerning Swearing, it is ≈øignified, That not onely Chri≈øts death, but his life al≈øo, &c. are meritorious, where it is ≈øayd: Who≈øoeuer wilfully Zechar. 5.4.5 See Chap. 73. for≈øweare them≈øelues vppon Chri≈øts Holy Euangely, they vtterly for≈øake Gods mercy, goodne≈ø≈øe and truth, the merits of our Sauiour Chri≈øts Natiuity, Life, Pa≈ø≈øion, Death, Re≈øurrection, and A≈øcen≈øion; they refu≈øe the forgiuene≈ø≈øe of ≈øinnes promi≈øed to all penitent ≈øinners, the ioyes of Heauen, the company with Angels and Saints for euer. In Bapti≈øme we promi≈øed to renounce the Diuell and his ≈øugge≈øtions, wee promi≈øed to be (as obedient children) alwayes following Gods will and plea≈øure.

So in the T. 2. p. 195. Homily of the Re≈øurrection it is ≈øayd: Yee mu≈øt con≈øider that yee be therefore clean≈øed and renued, that yee ≈øhould from hencefoorth ≈øerue God in holine≈ø≈øe and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe all the dayes of your liues, that ye may reigne with him in euerla≈øting life.

In the ≈øecond T. 2. p. 186. Homily of the Pa≈ø≈øion it is ≈øayd: Now it remaineth that I ≈øhewe vnto you, how to apply Chri≈øts death and pa≈øsion to our comfort, as a medicine to our wounds, ≈øo that it may worke the ≈øame effect in vs wherefore it was giuen, namely, the health and ≈øaluation of our ≈øoules. The Prophet David ≈øaid: P≈ø. 55.17. Evening and morning and at noone will I pray and cry aloud: and hee ≈øhall heare my voyce. div.head: CHAP. 46. Of the publike reading of the holy Scriptures, as al≈øo the Homilies, and of making an Exhortation in publike.
div.p: IN the Preface afore the Common prayer it is ≈øaid: The ancient fathers for a great advancement of godline≈ø≈øe ≈øo ordered the matter, that all the whole Bible (or the greate≈øt part thereof) ≈øhould be read over once every yeare, intending thereby that the Clergy, and e≈øpecially ≈øuch as were Mini≈øters of the Congregation, ≈øhould (by often reading and meditation of Gods Word) be ≈øtirred up to godline≈ø≈øe them≈øelves, and be more able to exhort others by whole≈øome doctrine, and to confute them that were adver≈øaries to the truth. And further that the people (by dayly hearing of holy Scripture read in the Church) ≈øhould continually profit more and more in the knowledge of God, and be the more inflamed with the love of his true religion. What care hereto our fathers have had, may appeare out of the ≈øacred Kalender, and out of the order how the P≈øalter is appointed to be read, and out of the order how the re≈øt of the holy Scripture (be≈øide the P≈øalter) is appointed to be read; all which are ≈øet before the Common prayer.

It is recorded in the Acts of the Apo≈øtles, that at Antioch in Pi≈øidia, in the Synagogue on the Sabbath day, there was theAct. 13.15. reading of the Law and the Prophets. In another place it is ≈øaid: Mo≈øes of old time hath in every City them that preach him, beingAct. 15. ‚Ä¢ 1. read in the Synagogues every Sabbath day. Saint Paul ≈øaith to the Colo≈øsians: When this Epi≈øtle
is read among≈øt you, cau≈øe that it beCol. 4.16. read al≈øo in the Church of the Laodiceans: and that yee likewi≈øe read the Epi≈øtle from Laodicea.

Of reading the Homilies.Concerning reading the Homilies the Sermons ≈øet forth by the publike authoritie of the Church, in the Preface publi≈øhed afore them it is ≈øaid: Con≈øidering how nece≈ø≈øary it is that the Word of God, which is the onely food of the ≈øoule, and that mo≈øt excellent light that we mu≈øt walke by, in this our mo≈øt dangerous pilgrimage, at all convenient times be preached unto the people, that thereby they may both learne their duty towards God, their Prince, and their neighbours, according to the minde of the Holy Gho≈øt, expre≈ø≈øed in the Scriptures: and al≈øo to avoide the manifold enormities which heretofore by fal≈øe doctrine have crept into the Church of God: and how that all they which are appointed Mini≈øters, have not the gift of preaching ≈øufficiently to in≈øtruct the people, which is committed unto them, whereof great inconveniences might ri≈øe, and ignorance ≈øtill be maintained, if ≈øome hone≈øt remedy be not ≈øpeedily found and provided. The Queenes mo≈øt excellent Maje≈øtie, tendering the ≈øole health of her loving ≈øubjects, & the quieting of their coÃÑ≈øciences, in the chiefe & principall points of Chri≈øtian religion, and willing al≈øo by the true ≈øetting forth, and pure declaring of Gods Word, which is the principal guide & leader runto all godlines and vertue, to expell & drive away as well all corrupt, vicious, and ungodly living, as al≈øo erroneous and poy≈øoned doctrines, tending to ≈øuper≈øtition and Idolatry: hath by the advi≈øe of her mo≈øt honourable Coun≈øellors, for her di≈øcharge in this behalfe, cau≈øed a booke of Homilies, which heretofore was ≈øet forth by her mo≈øt loving brother, a Prince of mo≈øt worthy memorie, Edward the ≈øixt, to bee printed anew, wherein are contained
certaine whole≈øome and godly exhortations, to move the people to honour and wor≈øhip Almighty God, and diligently to ≈øerve him, every one according to their degree, ≈øtate, & vocation. And in the latter part of the Preface it is ≈øaid: That all her people, of what degree or condition ≈øoever they be, may learne how to invocate, and call upon the name of God, and know what duty they owe both to God and man: ≈øo that they may pray, beleeve, and worke according to knowledge, while they ≈øhall live here, and after this life bee with him that with his blood hath bought us all. And at the end of the fir≈øt Tome of the Homilies it is ≈øaid concerning the Homilies of the ≈øecond Tome, Hereafter ≈øhall follow ≈øermons of fa≈øting, praying, alme≈ødeeds, &c. with many other matters, as well fruitfull as nec√®≈ø≈øarie to the edifying of Chri≈øtian people, and the increa≈øe of godly living. From al which afore≈øaid delivery it is mo≈øt manife≈øt, that the one only end, why the reverend Fathers, and the mo≈øt learned Doctors of the Church compo≈øed the ≈øermons commonly called Homilies, was for the edification of the congregations in holine≈ø≈øe and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe; and for a helpe unto Mini≈øters, that with the ≈øaid ≈øacred ≈øermons the people committed to their charge might be the more in≈øtructed in the faith and life of the true Chri≈øtian religion. As therefore we have received from our fathers the CommoÃÑ prayer, as a forme of prayer, thank≈øgiving, and confe≈ø≈øion: ≈øo ought wee not to receive from our fathers hands their booke of Sermons the Homilies, as a forme of whole≈øome words, in faith and love which is in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus? Saint Paul charged Timothy to hold fa≈øt the2 Tim. 1.13. Rom. 6.17. forme of ≈øound words, which he had heard of him, in faith and love, which
is in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus. Let any one unpartially weigh every particular ≈øentence in the booke of Homilies, and there will appeare nothing but Chri≈øtian faith and godly love intended and held forth therein.

Moreover, ought wee reverently to heare the Sermons of ≈øuch as bee but young Students in Divinity? and ought we not with great reverence to attend unto the Homilies the Sermons ≈øet forth by the chiefe≈øt Divines in the whole Church of our Land?We ought not to be partiall towards the e≈øtabli≈øhed Doctrine of our Church. We commonly a≈øcribe great authoritie unto the ≈øpirit of the Church, accounting her Common prayer profitable for us to pray with unto Almighty God: We a≈øcribe great authoritie unto the ≈øpirit of the Church, accounting her tran≈ølation of the Scriptures into our mother tongue to be faithfull, and meet for vs both to heare and read, yea and to ≈øettle our beliefe therein; and ought we not al≈øo to a≈øcribe great authoritie unto the ≈øpirit of the Church, in her1 The≈ø. 5.20. prophecying or ≈øermon making, her compo≈øing of the Homilies for our in≈øtruction in the Doctrine of the holy Scriptures? Wee pray unto God as her wi≈øedome hath pre≈øcribed; we heare and read for holy Scripture, as her wi≈øedome hath tran≈ølated; and ought we not with like con≈øcionable re≈øpect to heare and read the exhortations, interpretations, applications, &c. in her Homilies ≈øet forth for Doctrine, refutation, correction, and in≈øtruction in righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, as her wi≈ødome hath delivered unto us? The great authority of the deliveries in the Homilies may appeare unto us out of this con≈øideration; When wee heare a Pa≈øtour, Curate, or Lecturer preach, wee heare
deliveries which are but the wi≈ødome of a private Mini≈øter: But when wee heare a Homily read, wee heare deliveries, which are the wi≈ødome of the Church, or for approbation whereof the whole Churches Clergie have written theirSee the Epi≈øtle to the Reader, and the Adverti≈øement afterward. Of the Curates making a ≈øhort exhortation to the people, when iu≈øt occa≈øion is thereunto. a≈ø≈øent.

Concerning exhortation in publike, it is ≈øaid in the Rubricke after the Nicene Creed: After ≈øuch ≈øermon, homily, or exhortation, the Curate ≈øhall declare unto the people, whether there be any holy-dayes, or fa≈øting dayes the weeke following, and earne≈øtly exhort them to remember the poore, ≈øaying one or moe of the≈øe ≈øentences following, as hee thinketh mo≈øt convenient by his di≈øcretion.

In the T. 2. p. 138. Homily of Common prayer and Sacraments a ≈øaying of Iu≈øtinus Martyr is related, viz. Vpon the Sunday a≈ø≈øemblies are made, both of them that dwell in Cities, and of them that dwell in the Countrey al≈øo. In the fir≈øt part of the T. 2. p. 3. Homily concerning the right u≈øe of the Church, there is mentioned what the Ruler of the Temple in Antiochia ≈øignified unto Paul and Barnabas, after the le≈ø≈øon or reading of the Law and Prophets: viz. If any of you have any exhortation to make unto the people,Acts 13.15. ≈øay it. That exerci≈øe, wch now is coÃÑmonly called preaching, an≈øwereth much to the afore≈øaid exhortation: yea, exhortation is part of a preaching, as Paul ≈øaith:1 Cor. 14.3. He that prophe≈øieth, ≈øpeaketh unto men to edification, and exhortation, and comfort. But the exhortation here now meant, is a ≈øhort ≈øpeech made unto the
people, which is allowed by authority, yea, required in ≈øundry ca≈øes: As when a briefe is read, then to exhort the people untoRom. 12.13. 2 Cor. 9 5. contribution, by alleaging ≈øome Scriptures and rea≈øons whereby the more to move them to the ≈øame. When poore parties are to be married, and doe de≈øire an Offering, then anHeb. 10.24. Gal. 2.10. 1 Tim. 6.17, 18. exhortation may be made unto the Congregation, for to ≈øtirre them unto liberality. div.head: CHAP. 47. Of expounding the Scriptures, and of preaching, al≈øo of peoples hearing ≈øermons.
div.p: IN the fir≈øt part of the T. 2. p. 4. Homily concerning the right u≈øe of the Church, it is ≈øaid, That it is convenient that the Scriptures of God, and ≈øpecially the Go≈øpell of our Saviour Chri≈øt ≈øhould be read and expounded to us that be Chri≈øtians in our Churches, &c. It is written in Nehemiah, that the Prie≈øts read in the Law of God di≈øtinctly, and gave theNeh. 8.7, 8. ≈øen≈øe, and cau≈øed the people to under≈øtand the reading.

Of Preaching.Concerning preaching, the afore≈øaid part of that Homily al≈øo delivereth: In Luke ye reade how Ie≈øus according to his accu≈øtomed u≈øe came into the Temple, and how the booke of I≈øaias the Prophet was delivered him, how hee read a Text therein, and made a Luke 4.16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21. ≈øermon upon the ≈øame.

In the fir≈øt part of the T. 1. p. 54. Homily concerning falling from God, it is ≈øaid: God doth ≈øend his Me≈ø≈øengers, the true preachers of his Word, to I≈øa. 58.1. admoni≈øh and

The 45. con≈øtitution of the Church is: Every beneficed man allowed to bee a preacher, and re≈øiding on his benefice, having no lawfull impediment, ≈øhall in his owne Cure, or in ≈øome other Church or Chappell where he may conveniently, neare adjoyning, (where no preacher is) preach one ≈øermon every ≈øunday of the yeare, wherein he ≈øhall ≈øoberly and ≈øincerely 2 Tim. 2.15. divide the word of truth, to the glory God, and to the 1 Cor. 14.12. div.p: IN the beginning of the Service of Commination, it is ≈øaid: Brethren, in the Primitive Church there was a godly di≈øcipline, that at the beginning of Lent, ≈øuch per≈øons as were notorious offenders, were put to open penance, and puni≈øhed in this world, that their ≈øoules might be ≈øaved in the day of the Lord: and that others admoni≈øhed by their example, might be the more afraid to offend.
